bibl.title: Gwoo Shee Ah Look v. United States. Stipulation.
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

msIdentifier.repository: National Archives and Records Administration, Seattle Branch, Washington
msIdentifier.collection: RG 21: US District Court, Western Division of Washington, Seatle

div1.p: In the District Court of the United States for the District of Oregon.
In re Chin You Gen, Petitioner. Portland, Oregon, Monday, April 20, 1914.

The Petitioner is a Chinese woman, married to and the wife of one Lim Chuck. She was ordered deported by the government authorities on the ground that she was engaged in prostitution, and she brings this proceeding to obtain her discharge, asserting that she was not accorded a full and fair hearing by the Immigration authorities.

It appears that she and her husband were apprehended by the police officers in this city in a raid made by them November 4, 1913. The Inspector of the Immigration service at Portland was notified of the arrest, and on the day named visited the City Hall, took a statement from the Petitioner and from her husband, neither being present when the statement of the other was made, and then Petitioner was thereupon, by the Immigration Commissioner, ordered confined in the City Jail where she was kept in close confinement, denied the right to interview her friends or her attorney, or to communicate with any one except by authority of the Commissioner until the 10th of November, although the Commissioner was notified that she had an attorney who desired to communicate with her.

On November 10th, some six days after her arrest, she was again taken before the Commissioner, notified that she would have a hearing and that she was entitled to an attorney if she desired one. Her statement was again taken by the Commissioner and
reduced to writing. She cannot speak English and all her statements were made through an interpreter employed by the Immigration service. After this statement was taken on the 10th of November, her attorney was allowed to consult with her, but on the 17th of November, seven days later and after she had been accorded the service of an attorney, the Inspector took the testimony of the two police officers who made the arrest, and the vital testimony upon which the order of deportation was based, without her presence or the presence of her attorney, and denied the right of her counsel to be present at the hearing or to cross examine the witnesses. Her counsel thereupon requested the privilege of producing witnesses to testify before the Commissioner on her behalf and this was denied, but he was advised that he might submit affidavits from these witnesses or parties whom he desired to call, and the Commissioner would then determine whether or not in his judgment the testimony was material and should be made a part of the record.

The record as thus made up, without the Petitioner being present at any of the examinations and being represented either in person or by counsel, was transmitted to Washington, and based upon that the order of deportation was issued.

Now, the enforcement of the Immigration Laws is vested by Congress in an Executive Department and the action of that Department is not reviewable by the courts unless it is made to appear that the proceedings is maufestly unfair and the action of the officers such as to prevent a fair investigation, or that there was a manifest abuse of the discretaion committed to them by the Statute. In all other cases the courts have held that the order of the Executive Officers within the authority of the Statute is final and that the
courts cannot review their findings nor disturb their proceedings.

Now, the rules of the Department have provided that upon the receipt of the warrant of arrest an alien shall be taken before the person or persons therein described and granted a hearing to enable him to show cause, if any, why he should not be deported, and during the course of the hearing the alien shall be entitled to inpect the warrant of arrest and all the evidence on which it is issued, not at such stage thereof as the Immigration Officers may deem proper, shall be permitted the advice and assistance of course and if counsel is seelected, the rules provide that he shall be allowed to present during the further conduct of the hearing, to inpsect the record, make copy of the minutes of the hearings so fasr as they may have been presented, and to offer evidence to meet any evidence theretofore at thereafter presented by the government.

The only question in this case is whether the Petitioner was accorded such a hearing and in my judgment she was not. The Immigration Authorities under the decisions of the court and the rules of the Department, any conduct such preliminary investigation as they may deem wise or proper, may take such statements of parties prior to the formal hearing as they may deem expedient without the presence of the alien and without the alien being represented by counsel, but at some stage of the proceedings, before the warrant of deportation issues, the rules prescribe and common consideration for the rights of an individual demand that the alien shall have an opportunity to present such evidence as he may have to show that he is not within the meaning of the law and should not be deported, and that the right was denied the Petitioner in this case. After she had been accorded by the Commissioner the right and privilege of counsel, her counsel
was denied the right to be present at any of the hearings, to cross examine any of the witnesses, or to produce anty witnesses on behalf of the Petitioner, except that he was permitted to submit such affidavitss as he could procure, and these affidavits were transmitted as part of the record.

Now, in the United States vs Sibray, 178 Fed. 144, it was held that the hearing provided for by the rules contemplated a hearing at which an alien is allowed to be present, to confronted with the witnesses against him and to have full opportunity to cross examine, and such was the decision in Hanges vs. Whitfield, 209 Fed. and is the effect of Roux vs. Commissioner, 203 Fed. The doctine seems to be that no person can be deprived of his liberty and deported without an opportunity to show his right to remain and to present such evidence to the officers whose duty it is to pass upon this evidence.

"Now, the warrant of deportation was issued by the authorities at Washington based upon the record as made up before the Commissioner and it seems to me that under all the authorities and under all the rules of procedure the Petitioner in this case should have been allowed to have appeared wither in person or by counsel, at the proceedings which took place after she had been accorded counsel, and that was on the 10th of November, but notwithstanding that the Commissioner took the testimony of the two material witnesses without the presence of the Petitioner and denied the right of ehr counsel to be present at that hearing, and that, it seems to me, was a violatic of the rules prescribed by the Department."
The Petitioner is entitled to her discharge.
